Okay, let's see. The person is a manager who wrote a fake customer review about their coworker to improve her work ethic. The coworker was really lazy, and the manager tried talking to her before but it didn't work. The coworker had a friend who was the owner's daughter, which is why she wasn't fired. The manager found out that the coworker reads reviews and is self-conscious, so they wrote a fake negative review. The coworker then changed her behavior, got less piercings, changed her hair color, and became a model employee. Now the manager feels guilty.

So the question is whether the author is in the wrong. The user thinks they are, but wants to know others' opinions.

I need to decide if the manager did something wrong. Well, writing fake reviews is generally unethical. Even if the intention was good—to improve the coworker's performance—it's a deceptive action. The manager bypassed proper channels. Instead of addressing the issue through the owner, as they should, they took matters into their own hands. Also, the coworker might not have known the review was fake, so the manager manipulated her self-esteem and work habits. Even though the coworker improved, the method used was underhanded. The manager could have talked to the coworker again, documented the issues, or worked with the owner to address the problem. Using a fake review is a form of harassment or bullying. So, yeah, the manager is in the wrong. Answer A.
